div.l: And grathen̄ hom ⁊and took her hors anon̄
And eke her mele and on her weye thei gon
And ate mylle yit they took her cake
Of half a busshell floure ful wel I bake
Thus is the proude Millere wel I bete
And hath I lost the grynding of his whete
And paid for the souper eueri dell
Of Aleyn and of Iohn that bete him wel
His wyf is swiued ⁊and his douȝter als
Lo such it is a Mellere to be fals
And therfore this prouerbe is seid ful soth
Him dar nat mene well þᵗat euell doth
A guylour shal him self guiled be
And god that sitteth high in mageste
Saue all this company gret ⁊and small
Thus haue I aquitt the Miller in my tale
A Prolog of the Cook of London̄

The cook of london
whill the Reue spak ·

For Ioye him thouȝt ·
he clawed him on the bak /

Ha ha quod
he for cristes pasioıı̄un ·

This Miller hath a sharp̄
conclusioıı̄un /
Vpon his argument of herbergage
Wel said Salamon̄ in his language
Ne bringe nat eueri man̄ into thin hous
For herberwing be niȝt is perlous
Wel auȝt a man auised for to be
Whom that he brouȝt in to his priuete
I pray to god so yeue me sorwe ⁊and care
If euer sith I hight hogge of ware
Herd I a Miller better sette a werke
He had a Iape of malice in the derke
And therfore if ye vouchesaf to hiere
But god forbede that we stinten hiere
A tale of me that am a pore man̄
I woll you telle as wel as euer I can̄
A litill Iape that fell in oure cite
Oure oost ansuerd ⁊and seid I graunt it the
Now tell on Roger Cook that it be good
For many a pasty hast thou late blood
And many a Iacke of Douer hast thou sold
That hath be twies hoot ⁊and twyes cold
Of many a Pilgrym hast thou had cristes curs
For of thi parcell that they fare the wers
That they haue ete with the stubbed goos
For in thi shoppe is many a flye loos
Now telle on gentill Roger be thi name
But yit I pray the be nat wroth for game
A man may sey soth in game ⁊and play
Thou seist full soth quod Roger be my fay
But soth play quade play as þᵉ flemyng seith
And there Henry baillif be thi feith
Be thou nauȝt wroth or we departen hiere
Thouȝ that my tale be of an hostelere
But natheles I wil nat telle it yit
But or we departen̄ I wys thou shalt be quit
And ther with all he lough ⁊and made a chere
And seid his tale as ye shal aftir hiere
A Tale of the Cook of London̄
A Prentice whilom duellid in oure Cite
And of craft of Vitaillers was he
Gaylard he was as goldfynch in the shawe
Broun̄ as a bery a propir short felawe
With lockes blake I kempt full fetisly
Daunce he coude so wel ⁊and so iolily
That he was callid Perkyn reuelour
He was as full of loue and paramour
As is the hyve full of hony swete
Wel was the wenche that with him miȝt mete
At eueri bridale wold he synge and hoppe
He loued better the tauerne than the shoppe
For whan ther was any marieng in chepe
Out of the shoppe thider wold he lepe
Til that he had all the siȝt I seyn
And daunced well he wold nat come agein
